item.description: Matt Graham's brilliant bronze in the dual moguls, and the incredible response from his teammates, proved to everyone that he is the true leader of this Winter Olympic squad.

item.description: An inspired Alex de Minaur produces one of the biggest wins of his career, lifting the Rotterdam Open title by beating red-hot Felix Auger-Aliassime.

item.title: Whooping cough cases hit record high after 'potentially catastrophic' vaccine rate drop
item.description: A "potentially catastrophic" decline in Australia's childhood vaccination rates has contributed to the sharpest increase in cases of whooping cough in 35 years, infectious diseases experts say.

item.title: India and Pakistan refuse handshakes before and after contentious T20 World Cup clash
item.description: India and Pakistan decline to shake hands before and after the most-anticipated game of the T20 World Cup, with India easily winning by 61 runs to secure its Super 8 spot.

item.title: Queensland school teacher calls for endometriosis support after fundraising for surgery
item.description: After years of unsuccessful endometriosis treatments, Inez Goves underwent a hysterectomy thanks to an online fundraiser. But her symptoms returned, prompting more surgery and calls for greater support for the illness.

item.description: Angus Taylor wrote to the prime minister pitching the plan just days after being elected leader of the Liberal Party.

item.description: A leaked copy of the Liberal Party's migration policy prepared before Sussan Ley was ousted included plans to "elevate" the current non-binding Australian values statement.

item.description: New South Wales and Queensland can now select players who are New Zealand and England internationals after the NRL confirmed a major change to the State of Origin eligibility rules.

item.title: Australian women and children with links to ISIS forced to head back to camp in Syria
item.description: A group of Australian families with links to Islamic State fighters are forced to turn around after leaving a camp in Syria to try and begin their journey home to Australia.

item.description: Australia is on the cusp of a group stage exit from the T20 World Cup after crashing to an eight-wicket loss against tournament co-hosts Sri Lanka.

item.description: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un unveils new housing development in the country's capital, Pyongyang, to repay the "young martyrs" killed fighting in Ukraine.

item.title: Angus Taylor bets on migration politics amid global rightward shift
item.description: If migration is treated primarily as a cultural fault line, rather than an economic system embedded in national growth, the debate will remain loud. The structural reform will remain unfinished.

item.description: High levels of lead contamination have been found in dust samples taken from suburban locations close to Nyrstar's Hobart zinc smelter, documents obtained by the ABC show.

item.title: Interest rate hike worries? Here's some good news
item.description: Fresh warnings of further rate rises have been enough to send shivers up the collective spine of new homeowners, but if there's any comfort to be had, it's this: Don't believe a word of the forecasts.

item.description: Australia's anti-slavery commissioner calls for tough new laws forcing companies to take slavery in their supply chains seriously, as Ansell and Kmart face scrutiny.

item.description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese insists the federal government will not repatriate the Australian families with links to Islamic State fighters who remain in Syria.

item.title: Brain expert recommends learning new skills, taking on new challenges for healthy aging
item.description: A brain health expert says you're never too old to learn new skills, as Queenslanders take on fresh challenges such as Pilates, running, and even a law degree later in life.

item.description: AFL chief operating officer Tom Harley insists the league's polarising Opening Round is here to stay, declaring it crucial to the competition's growth in northern markets.

item.description: French authorities seized a 2.4-tonne drug shipment near French Polynesia during a joint operation with the United States.

item.description: More than 2,000 doctors responded to the Medical Workforce Wellbeing Survey last year, which polled the wellbeing of medical clinicians state-wide.

item.description: Cronulla duo Briton Nikora and Addin Fonua-Blake have both praised the rule changes that will give the pair a chance at State of Origin football they thought had long passed them by.

item.title: Private health premiums to rise at fastest rate in almost a decade

item.description: News from the world of finance and business. Top stories in text, video and audio. Business video news bulletin. Features and analysis.

item.title: Mother of former Manly player Keith Titmuss breaks silence on lawsuit against NRL club

item.title: Man arrested after fatal Merrylands stabbing escaped care 10 days before attack, health authorities say
item.description: A man arrested after a fatal stabbing in Merrylands escaped from mental health care while being transferred between hospitals more than a week ago, health authorities say.

item.title: Father whose son died in house fire accuses lawyer at coronial inquiry of 'degrading him'
item.description: The father, in an emotional outburst, told the inquest he had spent thousands of dollars on psychiatric and hypnotherapy appointments so he could move on from the tragedy.

item.description: Australia's Ally Hickman has to wait another day for the women's snowboard slopestyle final, as a snowstorm hits Livigno and causes scheduling delays.

item.description: Peter John Howlett, who allegedly used a fishing trawler to import illicit drugs into Australia, is refused bail by Mackay magistrate concerned for his safety.

item.description: The two-time Democratic presidential hopeful remembered for powerful speeches died peacefully surrounded by loved ones, his family said.

item.description: In the 1994 French play Art, Serge spends 160,000 euros on an all-white painting, horrifying his friend Marc. It might just wreck their decades-long friendship.

item.description: Biosecurity Tasmania has introduced stricter requirements for Tasmania's salmon companies reporting on farmed fish deaths — but whether the public finds out is another matter.

item.description: British economist Gary Stevenson is on a speaking tour, warning Australia will follow the path of the UK with "poverty exploding" unless politicians deal with inequality.

item.description: Riders embroiled in a dispute over pay and conditions with food delivery company HungryPanda in Sydney say Chinese police have asserted pressure back home to stop them protesting.

item.title: Private health insurance customers stung by exclusions after downgrading from gold policies
item.description: Australians are increasingly downgrading their health cover, with 360,000 people leaving gold policies since 2020. But some have been left out of pocket for surgeries they thought they were covered for.

item.title: Aerials delay is not unusual, as snow causes chaos at Milano Cortina 2026 Winter Olympics
item.description: Delays are nothing new in skiing events, with weather and light a constant battle for event organisers. However, the Australian aerials team has an unusual method to handle the disruption.

item.description: A few years ago, Charleville's main street had lost its spark, with storefronts empty and windows shuttered. So, what does it take to bring a main street back to life?

item.description: In the 1990s, a group of Indigenous women were accused of fabricating claims of sacred sites to stop the construction of a bridge south of Adelaide. It was a decision that has impacted a community for decades.

item.description: Jan Twomey bought a house on Hobart's eastern shore just over a year ago, knowing full well it was across from a zinc smelter. But news of high levels of lead detected in dust samples has her concerned.

item.description: Elena wants people with OCD to know they're not alone. But how well do Australians understand the condition?

item.description: Mary Fowler is expected to be named in Australia's Women's Asian Cup squad on Thursday despite having played limited minutes in her return from an ACL injury.

item.description: Iran says it temporarily closed the Strait of Hormuz — a vital international shipping route — as it entered a new round of talks with the US over its nuclear capabilities.

item.description: Real Madrid forward Vinícius Júnior accuses an opponent of racially abusing him during a Champions League game against Benfica, leading to the game being halted for nearly 10 minutes.

item.description: Two people have been charged after police allegedly found drugs, utensils and cash at an Airlie Beach property.

item.description: The ABC's managing director says its current Adelaide bureau could be redeveloped in a similar way to an apartment building nearby, while the premier says affordable apartments will still be included on the new CBD site.

item.description: Wage rises are not keeping up with inflation, meaning household budgets are being increasingly squeezed with inflation outpacing wages growth.

item.description: Ahead of the inaugural meeting of US President Donald Trump's Board of Peace, charged with leading the way forward in Gaza, Indonesian President Prabowo Subianto faces perhaps his most significant foreign policy test yet.

item.title: Is it ever a good idea to stay together for the kids?

item.description: For the first time since 2009, Australia won't advance from the group stage of a cricket World Cup and some of the game's greatest ever players are demanding answers.

item.title: Launceston Council scraps 4-day work week plan after backlash from business sector
item.description: A Tasmanian council's move to introduce a four-day work week, in part to attract and retain staff, has been abandoned after pushback by a business lobby group and what has been described as "unacceptable hostility" towards staff on social media.

item.description: Major car brands are staring down the barrel of multi-million-dollar penalties for exceeding their emissions, the first results of the federal government's climate laws for new vehicles have revealed.

item.description: A driver charged over a double-fatal crash used a staff pass to escape hospital the day before an alleged Sydney stabber fled the same mental health facility.

item.title: Tackling 'blatant' fake discounting, restoring consumer trust among ACCC's priorities for 2026
item.description: ACCC chair Gina Cass-Gottlieb outlines the consumer watchdog's priorities for 2026, including targeting "blatant" fake discounting.

item.title: Danielle Scott wins silver medal in women's aerials event at 2026 Milano Cortina Winter Olympics
item.description: Danielle Scott ends a 12-year drought for Australia by winning the silver medal in the women's aerials final at the Milano Cortina Winter Olympics.

item.title: Ukraine reclaims more than 200 square kilometres of territory as Elon Musk blocks Russian army's internet access
item.description: Ukraine has made its largest battlefield gains in more than two and a half years, retaking more than 200 square kilometres of its territory from Russia in just five days, according to a new analysis.

item.title: Antarctic pioneer John King Davis's grave was unmarked – until now
item.description: Captain John King Davis was one of Australia's greatest Antarctic explorers, but for decades, his final resting place was an unmarked grave in Melbourne. Today, that will change.

item.title: Underground car park at Macquarie Point stadium no longer in plans, Hobart councillors told
item.description: Nearly a quarter of attendees are expected to drive to Tasmania's new AFL stadium, but the local council says it's been told an underground car park is no longer part of site plans.

item.title: Tasmanian EPA drops plan to implement tighter lead controls after pushback from Nyrstar smelter
item.description: Three years ago, Tasmania's environment watchdog proposed to tighten lead emission limits from Hobart's zinc smelter to bring the state into line with national standards — but after pushback from the operator, that plan was dropped.

item.title: Today in History, February 19: Britpop, beats and a lust for life on Trainspotting's deathless soundtrack
item.description: Most films are lucky to get just one needle-drop moment embedded in the Zeitgeist. Trainspotting boasted several.

item.title: Quiz: Which books are these literary quotes from?
item.description: Are you happiest with your nose in a book? Did you spend summer reading at the beach? This quiz is for you.

item.title: Government spending is creeping up and threatening Australia’s 'low-debt' status
item.description: Australia will cease to be a low-debt country and be more vulnerable in a future crisis without a combination of spending restraint and tax reform, a new report has warned.

item.title: Senate committee features climate disinformation, the Atlas Network, and Dr Karl's clash with One Nation
item.description: The scourge of AI-slopaganda, viral disinformation campaigns and online attacks against individuals and institutions is going to get far worse before it gets better, if the latest public hearings on the topic are any indication.

item.title: Perth couple Jonathan and Amy Carr-Knox locked in international surrogacy battle to bring home daughter
item.description: Jonathan and Amy had a child via surrogacy in Argentina. They have been stuck there for 12 months, unable to bring their daughter home.

item.title: Danielle Scott's Winter Olympic silver ends years of pain
item.description: In this most tension-filled Winter Olympic sport, it's no wonder tears are a by-product of both success and failure. Thankfully for Dani Scott, this time she was crying tears of pure joy.

item.title: Eight back-country skiers found dead, one missing after avalanche in California
item.description: Eight skiers have been found dead and one is missing after an avalanche in California, making it the deadliest avalanche in the US in forty years.

item.title: Cherbourg turns to emerging technology while it waits for $26m water treatment plant
item.description: Just three hours from Brisbane, the residents of Cherbourg need to boil the town water to make it safe to drink. Delays to a new water treatment plant have driven them to use emerging technology that creates clean water from thin air.

item.title: Fiji's former prime minister Frank Bainimarama charged with inciting mutiny
item.description: Long-serving Fiji prime minister Frank Bainimarama and a former police commissioner will face court on Tuesday on charges of mutiny.

item.title: Unemployment steady, ASX just misses record close, energy stocks bounce on oil spike — as it happened
item.description: A steady unemployment rate puts more pressure on interest rates, while solid company results and higher oil prices push the ASX to a near record close

item.title: Winter Olympics 2026: Dog invades cross-country skiing, Americans get engaged as Ally Hickman feels the pain — day 12 quick hits
item.description: A pair of US athletes announce their engagement as Ally Hickman's medal bid turns sour and a dog steals the show at the cross-country skiing. Here are the quick hits from day 12 at the Winter Olympics.

item.title: Moyne Shire Council never wanted Port Fairy's pool, yet it paid $3.4m for it
item.description: A Victorian community group promised its local shire a new pool would not cost it money once it was built. In less than three months, the promise was broken.

item.title: Man who died in Bruce Highway crash remembered as 'kindest bloke'
item.description: Mr Roberts died in a head-on collision with a truck on the Bruce Highway at Burpengary on Tuesday night.

item.title: Outback families hope for change amid review into Queensland Patient Travel Subsidy Scheme
item.description: The cost of living is hurting outback residents who need to travel for medical treatment. They say government subsidies need to increase as the price of everything continues to rise.

item.title: James and Sophie among West Australians keen to give back as regional doctors
item.description: After graduating six years apart at the same high school in Kalgoorlie, both James Gent and Sophie Barton are following their dream of becoming a doctor.

item.title: Winter Olympics 2026: Channel Nine reporter Danika Mason apologises after viral Today show cross
item.description: Danika Mason has apologised for letting her standards slip during a live cross to the Today show from the Winter Olympics in Milano Cortina.

item.title: Mark Zuckerberg tells court Meta no longer designs apps to maximise screen time
item.description: The Meta chief executive's comments were made in a landmark trial over youth social media addiction.

item.title: Indian university kicked out of summit for falsely claiming credit for Chinese-made robotic dog
item.description: An Indian professor has sparked ridicule after falsely suggesting a commercially available Chinese robot dog displayed at a major AI summit in New Delhi was developed by her university.

item.title: Home and businesses raided as Darwin NDIA employee arrested for alleged $5m NDIS fraud
item.description: A 47-year-old Darwin public servant has been arrested and charged for allegedly defrauding $5 million from the National Disability Insurance Scheme.

item.title: From crime heists to a BDSM love story, here's what's in cinemas this month
item.description: Australians will also finally be able to catch Sirât and The Voice of Hind Rajab, two movies that will be vying for Best International Film at the Academy Awards next month.

item.title: Brisbane's Lang Park concert cap almost doubles under new trial
item.description: A one-year trial will see the number of concerts at Brisbane's Lang Park almost double from 12 to 21 per year.

item.title: How exclusion orders could ban Australian citizens from returning home indefinitely
item.description: One of the Australian women being held in a Syrian refugee camp has been barred from returning home after being given a temporary exclusion order — but the ban may not be as temporary as the name implies.

item.title: SA secures Australian MotoGP, world-first street circuit announced
item.description: The South Australian government has confirmed the Australian MotoGP will move to Adelaide from 2027, bringing with it huge economic benefits, but the opposition and Greens say the state has other priorities.

item.title: The Kyneton women's football team's story was always about more than just one club
item.description: The women's team from Kyneton's 15-month public and bitter saga suggests it is the canary in the coal mine of a widespread issue for women's players across the country.

item.title: Unemployment rate remains at 4.1pc in January, leading to talk of another rate rise
item.description: Australia's unemployment rate remained at 4.1 per cent in January, with 17,800 more employed people.

item.title: Feed and water supplies dry up in NSW as drought tightens grip
item.description: Over this season's hot and dry summer in New South Wales, farmer Ryan Staniforth has spent much of his time carting water to keep his sheep alive.

item.title: BlueScope remains in race for Whyalla steelworks as analyst warns of market concentration
item.description: Twelve months since the Whyalla steelworks was forced into administration, the sale process has entered its final stages, with the number of interested buyers narrowing from a field of 70 to five. One of those already owns Australia's largest steelworks in Port Kembla.

item.title: Charlie Pickering on his ADHD, satire and the 'ludicrous' Trump era
item.description: Political satire occasionally comes at a price, but Charlie Pickering still believes the right joke at the right time can have a huge impact.

item.title: The heartwarming tribute to injured aerials star Laura Peel at the Winter Olympics
item.description: This Winter Olympics aerials competition saw plenty of Aussies achieve lifetime goals, but they never forgot the one person who was missing — injured champion Laura Peel.

item.title: Wayne Gardner, Casey Stoner slam Victorian government over Phillip Island MotoGP loss
item.description: Australian Motorcycle Grand Prix winner Wayne Gardner has lashed out at the Victorian government over the loss of the Phillip Island MotoGP, saying he has been left "disappointed" and "sad" by the decision.

item.title: Wayne Gardner disappointed Victoria won't host Australian MotoGP
item.description: Follow the latest headlines from ABC News, Australia's most trusted media source, with live events, audio and on-demand video from the national broadcaster.

item.title: Premier Chris Minns questions what went wrong amid Cumberland Hospital patient escapes
item.description: NSW Premier Chris Minns says it is "deeply distressing" that two mental health patients who escaped from the same Sydney hospital within 24 hours went on to allegedly kill three people between them.

item.title: Alcoa's environmental record 'disappointing' says WA premier after $55m payment for unlawful jarrah forest clearing
item.description: Roger Cook criticises Alcoa's environmental record for being "not at the level we expect", after the US mining giant agreed to pay $55 million for clearing a native jarrah forest in WA's south without approval.

item.title: Police commissioner claims drones over Moree will not be used for surveillance
item.description: Police will control drones from more than 600 kilometres away from a rural town battling high crime rates.

item.title: Adelaide Ice Arena charged after patrons hospitalised for alleged carbon monoxide exposure
item.description: Safework SA has launched criminal proceedings against the Adelaide Ice Arena, after hockey players and spectators were allegedly exposed to "significant levels" of carbon monoxide more than two years ago, leading to more than 40 hospitalisations.

item.title: Heavy rain through north Queensland leads to multiple floodwater rescues and Bruce Highway closures
item.description: Heavy rainfall across north Queensland has led to multiple rescues and the closure of several sections of the Bruce Highway.

item.title: Sydney businessman compiled reports for what he allegedly believed was Chinese intelligence, court hears
item.description: A LinkedIn introduction led to Australian businessman Alexander Csergo compiling reports for two people he believed worked for a Chinese intelligence agency in exchange for cash, a jury has heard.

item.title: In her memoir, Gisèle Pelicot reveals the secret love behind France's most infamous rape trial
item.description: The world knows Gisèle Pelicot as the woman who waived anonymity during France's most infamous rape trial. But in her new memoir she reveals an unexpected story — the boyfriend she kept hidden and the love that helped her face an open courtroom.

item.title: Dimboola gift shop firebombed days after police find illegal cigarettes
item.description: The small west Victorian town of Dimboola is the latest regional centre to be affected by the state's illicit cigarette trade and tobacco wars.

item.title: An avalanche in Northern California was the worst in the US for 40 years. Here's how it unfolded
item.description: An avalanche in California has left eight back-country skiers dead and one missing. Here's how it unfolded.

item.title: North Qld Anglican diocese given green light to sell properties to pay compensation
item.description: A successful Supreme Court application will allow the church to sell assets to help fund its commitments to victims of historical child abuse.

item.title: Rugby fans furious over 2027 Rugby World Cup ticket website crashes
item.description: Rugby fans from around the world are furious after failing to get tickets to the 2027 Men's World Cup due technical glitches and website crashes.

item.title: For salty South Australians, motorsport revenge is oh so sweet
item.description: The last Grand Prix in Adelaide was held in 1995 before its move across the border to Victoria. Now, Adelaide has poached the MotoGP — but will it be enough to appease resentful SA Formula One fans?

item.title: Hate laws put free speech at risk, constitutional expert tells NSW extremism inquiry
item.description: An influx of federal and state laws trying to curb hateful rhetoric after a wave of antisemitic attacks are risking free speech and could anger the public, a constitutional law expert warns.

item.title: Man charged with terrorism offences after phones seized in Sydney's south-west
item.description: A 31-year-old has been arrested a second time after police stopped and searched a vehicle in Yagoona and seized three mobile phones allegedly storing violent extremist material.

item.title: Free RSV flu vaccine for aged care residents to be rolled out in WA
item.description: After a horror flu season last year, free RSV vaccinations are being rolled out for the first time for older Western Australians living in residential aged care.

item.title: Canberra schoolboys face drug-affected driver who struck them outside St Edmund's College
item.description: Tayler Hazell is facing his victims in a sentencing hearing in the ACT Supreme Court. He struck two students in Canberra in a stolen car while high on drugs.

item.title: Hanson digs her heels in, Taylor goes on tour
item.description: This week, the new opposition leader revealed his shadow cabinet while Pauline Hanson spun through a cycle she knows well.

item.title: Vegetable scraps to be turned into bioenergy by Scenic Rim farm as part of $291 million project
item.description: A new $291 million project set to turn farm scraps to energy has begun construction in Queensland's Scenic Rim.

item.title: Tracking the US military build-up ahead of possible Iran attack
item.description: The steady flow of military assets moving towards Europe and the Middle East appears to be a warning that the US could be ready to attack Iran.

item.title: What is Skimo? The sport preparing to steal the show at the 2026 Milano Cortina Winter Olympic Games
item.description: Skimo, or ski mountaineering, is coming to the 2026 Winter Olympics. But what is the sport and why is it so exciting?

item.title: Two WA childcare providers fined after high-needs children wander off from care
item.description: One of Australia's biggest providers of before and after school care is fined after a five-year-old neurodivergent child escapes supervision unnoticed.

item.title: Court hears statement murdered woman Irma Palasics made after harrowing assault a year earlier
item.description: A statement made by murdered woman Irma Palasics after a burglary at her home a year prior is read to the ACT Supreme Court.

item.title: Racing NSW disqualifies stablehand and owner Brian Carey over racehorse death in Maryborough
item.description: Registered owner and stablehand Brian Carey is disqualified after being found guilty by Racing NSW of failing to ensure his racehorse, City Limits, had sufficient food and water.

item.title: Long-awaited rapid bus plan fails to reveal construction timeline or routes
item.description: After about a year of delays, the Tasmanian government has released its strategic business case for the Greater Hobart Rapid Bus Network, but a lot of the detail has not been included.

item.title: Salmon farm antibiotics found in native Tasmanian species kilometres away
item.description: An antibiotic used by the Tasmanian salmon farming industry is detected in native species more than 10km away from the closest fish operation using it.

item.title: Man accused of 'controlling' the lives of Venezuelan youth group granted bail
item.description: An alleged religious leader accused of "controlling every aspect" of the lives of a Venezuelan youth group has been granted release on strict home detention conditions by a South Australian court.

item.title: SA Premier Peter Malinauskas criticised over aged care workforce comments
item.description: South Australia's Premier Peter Malinauskas has been criticised across the political divide for comments he made asking One Nation voters "who's going to feed you and bathe you and wipe your bum when you're 90", but a government spokesperson says the comments have been mischaracterised.

item.title: Police investigate stabbing of 17-year-old at Geelong shopping mall
item.description: A 17-year-old boy has been taken to hospital with serious injuries after a suspected stabbing at the Market Square shopping centre in Geelong.

item.title: Winter Olympics 2026 quick guide: What to watch on Day 13
item.description: Find out what's on at the Winter Olympics in Milan.

item.title: Collingwood apologise after asking elderly members for donations via their wills
item.description: Collingwood have come under fire after a letter campaign requesting elderly members to amend their will in order to donate to the AFL club.
